The multi-year deal will give the AI firm access to “hundreds of thousands of state-of-the-art" Nvidia chips, as the company seeks vast…
items.content: OpenAI has struck a $38 billion agreement with Amazon Web Services (AWS) to secure cloud computing power from the tech giant, the ChatGPT maker announced Monday. The multi-year deal will give the AI firm access to “hundreds of thousands of state-of-the-art" Nvidia chips, as the company seeks vast…

items.title: OpenAI signs massive AI compute deal with Amazon
items.standfirst: Deal will provide access to hundreds of thousands of Nvidia chips that power ChatGPT.
items.content: On Monday, OpenAI announced it has signed a seven-year, $38 billion deal to buy cloud services from Amazon Web Services to power products like ChatGPT and Sora. It’s the company’s first big computing deal after a fundamental restructuring last week that gave OpenAI more operational and financial freedom from Microsoft. The agreement gives OpenAI access to hundreds of thousands of Nvidia graphics processors to train and run its AI models. “Scaling frontier AI requires massive, reliable compute,” OpenAI CEO Sam Altman said in a statement. “Our partnership with AWS strengthens the broad compute ecosystem that will power this next era and bring advanced AI to everyone.” OpenAI will reportedly use Amazon Web Services immediately, with all planned capacity set to come online by the end of 2026 and room to expand further in 2027 and beyond. Amazon plans to roll out hundreds of thousands of chips, including Nvidia’s GB200 and GB300 AI accelerators, in data clusters built to power ChatGPT’s responses, generate AI videos, and train OpenAI’s next wave of models.Read full article Comments

items.title: Microsoft to Buy AI Computing Power From IREN for $9.7 Billion
items.standfirst: Microsoft Corp. has signed a roughly $9.7 billion deal to buy artificial intelligence computing capacity from IREN Ltd., becoming the Australian company’s largest customer. Bloomberg's Caroline Hyde reports. (Source: Bloomberg)
items.content: Microsoft Corp. has signed a roughly $9.7 billion deal to buy artificial intelligence computing capacity from IREN Ltd., becoming the Australian company’s largest customer. Bloomberg's Caroline Hyde reports. (Source: Bloomberg)

items.title: Afghanistan struck by another powerful earthquake
items.standfirst: A powerful #earthquake killed at least 20 people in northern #Afghanistan, just months after the deadliest in the country's history. The 6.3-magnitude quake struck overnight near Mazar-e-Sharif, famous for its Blue #Mosque, which was partially damaged.
items.content: A powerful #earthquake killed at least 20 people in northern #Afghanistan, just months after the deadliest in the country's history. The 6.3-magnitude quake struck overnight near Mazar-e-Sharif, famous for its Blue #Mosque, which was partially damaged.

items.title: Second deadly earthquake in months strikes Afghanistan
items.standfirst: A 6.3 magnitude earthquake struck near Kholm, Afghanistan, causing damage and casualties, including the partial destruction of the historic Blue Mosque. Rescue efforts are underway, but poor infrastructure and reduced foreign aid pose significant challenges for the Taliban government in responding to this latest disaster, which follows a deadly earthquake in August that killed over 2,000 people.
items.content: A 6.3 magnitude earthquake struck near Kholm, Afghanistan, causing damage and casualties, including the partial destruction of the historic Blue Mosque. Rescue efforts are underway, but poor infrastructure and reduced foreign aid pose significant challenges for the Taliban government in responding to this latest disaster, which follows a deadly earthquake in August that killed over 2,000 people.

items.title: Powerful Afghan earthquake leaves at least 20 dead and hundreds injured
items.standfirst: Northern provinces of Balkh and Samangan worst hit by magnitude 6.3 quake, which also damaged Mazar-i-Sharif’s Blue MosqueA powerful 6.3 magnitude earthquake shook northern Afghanistan before dawn on Monday, killing at least 20 people and injuring more than 640 others, 25 critically, a disaster management official said. Health officials said the numbers could rise.The US Geological Survey said the quake’s epicentre was located 22km (14 miles) south-west of the town of Khulm, and that it struck at 12.59am at a depth of 28km (17 miles). Continue reading...

Health officials said the numbers could rise.The US Geological Survey said the quake’s epicentre was located 22km (14 miles) south-west of the town of Khulm, and that it struck at 12.59am at a depth of 28km (17 miles). items.title: Former top lawyer of Israeli army arrested for leaking video of prisoner abuse
items.standfirst: Israeli police arrested the military's former top lawyer, Yifat Tomer-Yerushalmi, who leaked a video showing the abuse of a Palestinian detainee. The video has triggered international outrage. France 24's Noga Tarnopolsky reports from Jerusalem.

items.title: Israel top military lawyer arrested after she admitted leaking video of soldiers’ abuse
items.standfirst: Rightwing politicians and pundits have called the soldiers accused of attack on Palestinian detainee ‘heroes’ and military investigators traitors Police in Israel have arrested and detained the military’s top legal officer after she admitted leaking footage of soldiers allegedly attacking a Palestinian detainee and then in effect lying about her actions to Israel’s high court.The military advocate general, Yifat Tomer-Yerushalmi, said in a resignation letter last week that she had authorised publication of the video to defuse attacks on military investigators and prosecutors working on the case. Continue reading...

clusters.title: Rescuers try to free man trapped in partly collapsed medieval tower in Rome
clusters.neutral_headline: Rescuers try to free man trapped in partly collapsed medieval tower in Rome

items.title: Rescuers try to free man trapped in partly collapsed medieval tower in Rome
items.standfirst: Official says there is evidence man is ‘still alive’ after collapse at Torre dei Conti, which was undergoing restoration worksRescue workers are trying to pull a man from the rubble of a medieval tower in central Rome that partly collapsed twice during renovations, trapping him on an upper floor and injuring another man.The Torre dei Conti, located close to the Roman Forum ruins, suffered an initial collapse just after 11.30am (1030 GMT) on Monday, with falling debris reportedly hitting a 64-year-old worker. Continue reading...
items.content: Official says there is evidence man is ‘still alive’ after collapse at Torre dei Conti, which was undergoing restoration worksRescue workers are trying to pull a man from the rubble of a medieval tower in central Rome that partly collapsed twice during renovations, trapping him on an upper floor and injuring another man.The Torre dei Conti, located close to the Roman Forum ruins, suffered an initial collapse just after 11.30am (1030 GMT) on Monday, with falling debris reportedly hitting a 64-year-old worker. Continue reading...

items.title: Medieval tower partially collapses in central Rome
items.standfirst: The Torre dei Conti medieval tower in central #Rome was under renovation when it partially collapsed on November 3 just after 11:30 am local time. One worker is believed to be trapped alive under rubble, while three others were evacuated, with one taken to hospital in critical condition, a firefighter spokesman told AFP. The tower is in a busy area, just off the Imperial Forum and close to the #Colosseum, #Italy's top tourist site.
items.content: The Torre dei Conti medieval tower in central #Rome was under renovation when it partially collapsed on November 3 just after 11:30 am local time. One worker is believed to be trapped alive under rubble, while three others were evacuated, with one taken to hospital in critical condition, a firefighter spokesman told AFP. The tower is in a busy area, just off the Imperial Forum and close to the #Colosseum, #Italy's top tourist site.

items.title: Trump administration will provide half of usual funds to Snap recipients in November
items.standfirst: Contingency funds will keep benefits going for nearly 42 million people in the food assistance program, Trump saysUS politics live – latest updatesThe Trump administration said it would provide partial relief to recipients of food stamps on Monday as the federal government shutdown approached a record-breaking length.Amid mounting uncertainty among the nearly 42 million people on the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (Snap), the Department of Agriculture said it would use contingency funds to keep benefits going, albeit just 50% of the usual funds recipients receive on their cards. Continue reading...

items.title: Leader of Spain's Valencia region resigns over handling of deadly 2024 floods
items.standfirst: The leader of Spain's Valencia region, Carlos Mazon, said on Monday he was stepping down one year after deadly floods that killed more than 230 people hit the region. Mazon, who has faced repeated calls for his resignation due to his handling of the natural disaster, said he was stepping down due to "hatred" being directed at him.
items.content: The leader of Spain's Valencia region, Carlos Mazon, said on Monday he was stepping down one year after deadly floods that killed more than 230 people hit the region. Mazon, who has faced repeated calls for his resignation due to his handling of the natural disaster, said he was stepping down due to "hatred" being directed at him.

items.title: Valencia leader resigns over handling of deadly floods
items.standfirst: A year after flash floods killed 229 people in the Valencia region, Carlos Mazón acknowledged "mistakes" were made.
items.content: A year after flash floods killed 229 people in the Valencia region, Carlos Mazón acknowledged "mistakes" were made.

items.title: Valencia president Carlos Mazón resigns over botched handling of deadly floods
items.standfirst: Leader of Spanish region’s People’s party had clung to power despite calls for him to stand down over 2024 disaster‘Mud on our hands; blood on his’: fury lingers one year after deadly floodsCarlos Mazón, the embattled president of the eastern Spanish region of Valencia, has bowed to public fury and political pressure by resigning over his botched handling of the deadly floods that killed 229 people in the area just over a year ago.Mazón, a member of the conservative People’s party (PP), had hung on despite calls for him to stand down after it emerged that he spent more than three hours having lunch with a journalist as the floods hit and people were drowning in their homes, garages and cars. Continue reading...

items.title: Sex Dolls, Boycotts, Protests: Furor in France as Shein Opens Paris Store
items.standfirst: France threatened to ban Shein after learning the Chinese-founded e-commerce giant was selling child-like sex dolls on its platform ahead of the opening of its first-ever permanent bricks-and-mortar location in Paris this week.
items.content: France threatened to ban Shein after learning the Chinese-founded e-commerce giant was selling child-like sex dolls on its platform ahead of the opening of its first-ever permanent bricks-and-mortar location in Paris this week.

items.title: French government threatens to ban Shein if child-like sex dolls reappear
items.standfirst: The French finance ministry says it will ban Chinese e-commerce giant Shein if child-like sex dolls reappear for sale on the site. Shein pulled the dolls after France's consumer watchdog said it discovered them last week. Under French law, distributing child sexual abuse material online is punishable by up to seven years in prison and a hefty fine. We bring you that story and more in this Monday's business news.
items.content: The French finance ministry says it will ban Chinese e-commerce giant Shein if child-like sex dolls reappear for sale on the site. Shein pulled the dolls after France's consumer watchdog said it discovered them last week. Under French law, distributing child sexual abuse material online is punishable by up to seven years in prison and a hefty fine. We bring you that story and more in this Monday's business news.

clusters.title: Trump administration says it will partially fund Snap food aid benefits– live
clusters.neutral_headline: Trump administration says it will partially fund Snap food aid benefits– live

items.title: Trump administration says it will partially fund Snap food aid benefits– live
items.standfirst: Trump administration says in court filing it plans to use emergency funds to partially cover November Snap benefits for millions of AmericansLooking ahead, on Wednesday, the supreme court will hear arguments on whether Donald Trump’s sweeping tariffs on dozens of countries are legal. It’s set to be one of the most consequential rulings on the expanse of Trump’s presidential power in his second term.My colleague, Eduardo Porter, has this helpful breakdown on the question at the heart of this case. A dozen states have challenged the president’s contention that the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA) of 1977 gives him the power to impose tariffs on imports from every country in the world to defend the nation from a several “threats” facing the US.Justices will focus much of their attention on whether IEEPA authorizes the president to levy a tariff – a word that is not mentioned in the text of the law and is, moreover, a form of taxation, over which, per the constitution, Congress has exclusive power.IEEPA gives the president authority “to deal with any unusual and extraordinary threat, which has its source in whole or substantial part outside the United States, to the national security, foreign policy, or economy of the United States, if the president declares a national emergency with respect to such threat”. Continue reading...
items.content: Trump administration says in court filing it plans to use emergency funds to partially cover November Snap benefits for millions of AmericansLooking ahead, on Wednesday, the supreme court will hear arguments on whether Donald Trump’s sweeping tariffs on dozens of countries are legal. It’s set to be one of the most consequential rulings on the expanse of Trump’s presidential power in his second term.My colleague, Eduardo Porter, has this helpful breakdown on the question at the heart of this case. A dozen states have challenged the president’s contention that the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA) of 1977 gives him the power to impose tariffs on imports from every country in the world to defend the nation from a several “threats” facing the US.Justices will focus much of their attention on whether IEEPA authorizes the president to levy a tariff – a word that is not mentioned in the text of the law and is, moreover, a form of taxation, over which, per the constitution, Congress has exclusive power.IEEPA gives the president authority “to deal with any unusual and extraordinary threat, which has its source in whole or substantial part outside the United States, to the national security, foreign policy, or economy of the United States, if the president declares a national emergency with respect to such threat”. Continue reading...

items.title: The president who cried tariffs: will the US supreme court challenge Trump’s trade war?
items.standfirst: The US high court will hear arguments on whether Trump’s erratic imposition of global tariffs is legally validDonald Trump thrives on emergencies. He cried havoc on the very first day of his second term, declaring a national emergency caused by an “invasion” of “illegal aliens” from Mexico. He has since invoked emergencies more than any president since the passage of the National Emergencies Act in 1976.Next Wednesday, he faces another of his own making, as the US supreme court hears oral arguments on whether his globe-shaking signature economic policy – tariffs – is legally valid. Continue reading...
items.content: The US high court will hear arguments on whether Trump’s erratic imposition of global tariffs is legally validDonald Trump thrives on emergencies. He cried havoc on the very first day of his second term, declaring a national emergency caused by an “invasion” of “illegal aliens” from Mexico. He has since invoked emergencies more than any president since the passage of the National Emergencies Act in 1976.Next Wednesday, he faces another of his own making, as the US supreme court hears oral arguments on whether his globe-shaking signature economic policy – tariffs – is legally valid. Continue reading...

items.standfirst: Fast-fashion retailer faces political anger, fury from workers and warnings it will damage city’s progressive imageThe online fast-fashion retailer Shein will open its first permanent bricks-and-mortar store in the world in Paris this week amid political outrage, fury from workers and warnings from city hall that it will damage the French capital’s progressive image.The Singapore-based clothing company, which was founded in China, has built a massive online business despite criticism over its factory working conditions and the environmental impact of low-cost, throwaway fashion. Continue reading...

Continue reading...

ai_summary: Shein, an online fast-fashion retailer, plans to open its first physical store in Paris.
The opening faces political opposition, worker anger, and concerns about the city's image.
The Singapore-based company has faced criticism regarding its factory working conditions.
Critics also cite the environmental impact of the company's low-cost, disposable fashion.
City officials have warned the store could damage Paris's progressive image.

clusters.title: Israel warns of intensifying attacks against Hezbollah
clusters.neutral_headline: Israel Warns of Intensifying Attacks Against Hezbollah

items.title: Israel warns of intensifying attacks against Hezbollah
items.standfirst: Israel has hinted at expanding airstrikes in Lebanon, accusing Hezbollah of rearming despite last year’s ceasefire. Lebanese residents say the truce feels one-sided, as Israel continues to hit Hezbollah positions in the south. The ceasefire’s terms remain murky, Hezbollah is meant to disarm only south of the Litani River, but Israel claims the group is still active and heavily armed, as FRANCE 24's Rawad Taha explains from Beirut.
items.content: Israel has hinted at expanding airstrikes in Lebanon, accusing Hezbollah of rearming despite last year’s ceasefire. Lebanese residents say the truce feels one-sided, as Israel continues to hit Hezbollah positions in the south. The ceasefire’s terms remain murky, Hezbollah is meant to disarm only south of the Litani River, but Israel claims the group is still active and heavily armed, as FRANCE 24's Rawad Taha explains from Beirut.

clusters.title: Mayor killed during Day Of The Dead festivities

items.content: A mayor has been shot dead in front of dozens of people in Mexico during Day Of The Dead festivities.

items.title: Mexican mayor killed during Day of the Dead celebrations
items.standfirst: Carlos Alberto Manzo Rodríguez, who was under police protection, was shot dead in front of dozens of peopleA mayor in Mexico’s western state of Michoacán was shot dead in a plaza in front of dozens of people who had gathered for Day of the Dead festivities, authorities have said.The mayor of the Uruapan municipality, Carlos Alberto Manzo Rodríguez, was gunned down Saturday night in the town’s historic centre. He was rushed to a hospital where he later died, according to state prosecutor Carlos Torres Piña. Continue reading...
items.content: Carlos Alberto Manzo Rodríguez, who was under police protection, was shot dead in front of dozens of peopleA mayor in Mexico’s western state of Michoacán was shot dead in a plaza in front of dozens of people who had gathered for Day of the Dead festivities, authorities have said.The mayor of the Uruapan municipality, Carlos Alberto Manzo Rodríguez, was gunned down Saturday night in the town’s historic centre. He was rushed to a hospital where he later died, according to state prosecutor Carlos Torres Piña. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A mayor was shot dead during Day of the Dead festivities in Mexico.
The mayor was killed in Uruapan, Michoacán, in front of dozens of people.
The mayor was under police protection at the time of the shooting.
The mayor was rushed to a hospital but later died.
Authorities have confirmed the mayor's death.
